instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on Apple logo
threads.message: So I have o nthe bench an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that the customer said he took to another shop and they said there is a problem with the power distribution on the LB. I was like what?! never heard that before. I checked it out and asked for history and he said his daughter was using it and it just stopped working. I powerd it on and the BL is not working but is will boot to Apple logo but gets stuck on an empty progress bar. I took the board out and <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> definitely suffered liquid damage as well as the resistors to the right of it. <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> has a tiny bit of dried stuff above it. My question is, neither one of these could cause the LB not to load the OS correct? I looked the whole board under MS and do not see liquid on the PCH side or by <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on Apple logo
threads.message:
Liquid spill can affect BIOS sometime.
Try known good working BIOS as first step; clean ME, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on Apple logo
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on Apple logo
threads.message: Liquid spill can affect the BIOS even if it didn't get liquid on it? Can you explain?
